title: Authoring

Browsing & searching
Editing documents
Creating sheets
Working with media



Basics

title: Browsing content
content:
Browsing content
Everything you need to know browse content on Document Authoring.





Tips
Here are some tips to get the most out of the browse and search views on Document Authoring.


style
center, container


spacing-top
800


spacing-bottom
400





Organizations and sites have configurations, folders and files do not. If you are in either an organization or site, the breadcrumb will expose a settings icon that allows you to set high performance settings for that area. This is currently limited to user permissions and AEM integrations.
Selecting one or more items will expand the Action Bar. The action bar will present many common actions for your content. If you feel an action is missing, there is likely an app (bulk ops) that can accept the URLs shared from the Action Bar.
Search is powerful, precise, and basic. Basic + precise can be both a positive and negative. Searching for "aem" will result in only getting lower case results. Searching for "AEM" will yield different results. There are common search recipes listed below.



Browse basics
Below you will find details about basic browsing. If you have browsed content with SharePoint or Google Drive, Document Authoring should feel intuitive. Clicking on the name of an item will take you to the item.










style
center, container


spacing
1000




Search
Get the most out of searching your content.


style
center, container


spacing-top
800


spacing-bottom
400





Searching the root of the site will include all languages. This may not be desirable and you may want to scope your search to a series of sub-folders.
Find & replace does not currently version on replace. Be absolutely sure you are making the desired replacement. If something goes wrong, you will need to restore from aem.page, aem.live or an older version. If you are unsure or want protections, ask an engineer to write a find & replace script.



Search query tips
A couple recipes to make searching easier.


style
center, container


spacing-top
800


spacing-bottom
400





Search by block name w/ all variations - class="name-of-block
Search by block name with no variations - class="name-of-block"
Search for link - href="https://url-of-link"
Search for all fragments - /fragments/
Search for image - src="https://url-of-link"



spacing-bottom
400

title: Authoring docs
content:
Authoring docs
Everything you need to know to create content in AEM Edge Delivery Services.





Concepts
There are a few concepts that can help you get the most out of Document Authoring.


style
center, container


spacing-top
800


spacing-bottom
400





The edit menu is contextual. Example: Clicking into a table will expose the edit table button in the edit menu.
Palettes stay open. Menus do not. Similar to Adobe Creative Cloud, larger palettes that may need to be used while working in the document will stay open. Library plugins can opt to close the library palette if the interaction should be a one-time event (like selecting a tag). Menus like the expanded text menu will close after click.
There can be subtle differences from other editors. Much like comparing Google Docs to Microsoft Word, Document Authoring does have subtle differences from existing authoring tools. We continue to refine these behaviors and try to take the best ideas where possible.



Basics
Below you will find details about basic editing. If you have made documents in Word or Google Docs, Document Authoring (DA) should feel familiar and intuitive.










style
center, container


spacing
1000




Tables
The table button is contextually aware. Clicking into a table will change the add table button to an edit table button.










style
center, container


spacing
1000




Text
Working with text should feel natural in Document Authoring.










style
center, container


spacing
1000

title: Authoring sheets
content:
Authoring sheets
How to work with sheets in DA.





Basics
Document Authoring sheets provide a way to work with spreadsheets. Here are a few tips to help get you started.


style
center, container


spacing-top
800


spacing-bottom
400





All sheet tabs are public by default. Because DA sheets are targeted towards public web content and not line of business applications, all sheets are public by default. If you would like a sheet to be private, you can prefix the sheet with "private-".
DA sheets are not designed to replace all Excel use cases. At the time of this writing, DA sheets do not have feature parity with Excel and Google Sheets. If you require conditional formatting, formulas, or you have 10,000+ rows, we recommend you keep this content in SharePoint / Google Drive and use AEM's content overlay feature.
Previewing a sheet saves the sheet. - Unlike DA docs, you need to manually preview and save your sheet.



Basics
Below you will find details about basic editing. If you have made spreadsheets in other applications like Excel or Google Sheets, Document Authoring (DA) should feel familiar and intuitive.










style
center, container


spacing
1000




Edit sheet details
You can use the edit sheet button to edit the sheet name or delete the sheet completely.










style
center, container


spacing
1000




Editing rows, columns, cells, and more
Right clicking into a cell can help you work with your content. You can add rows and columns, delete them, or even export your sheet as a CSV.










style
center, container


spacing
1000

title: Working with media
content:
Working with media





Information architecture
Dark Alley has three recommended patterns to handle media:

AEM Assets
Drag and drop
Media folder



background
#f1f1f1


spacing
1000




Supported media types
Dark Alley supports the following media types:

JPG
PNG
GIF
SVG
WebP
PDF



background
#FFF


spacing
1000




Media patterns explained
AEM Assets
You can store your media in AEM Assets. This is great for highly curated and re-used content.
Drag and drop
For those that want a more friction-free approach to handling media, you can drag any supported media onto a doc. This is, by far, the easiest method to get imagery into your docs. The file will be imported into the same folder as the document.
Media folder
DA provides basic media handling. If you do not have a license for AEM Assets, but wish to organize your media into a central location, we recommend using the media folder. Simply create a top-level folder called "media" and upload your content into it. You can open a media file, copy it to the clipboard, and paste it into your document.


background
#f1f1f1


spacing
1000




Content migrations
Because DA simply references media, it is possible to do bulk content migrations. This could be anything from changing the source image in place to using search & replace to change a file name. Please consider the following when making these types of changes:

All changes in bulk still require a re-preview of the consuming docs so Edge Delivery Services can re-process the changed media.
Please note any cache constraints if changing content in AEM Assets. Ensure that you can see the changes in your publish environment before asking Edge Delivery Services to re-preview your content.



background
#FFF


spacing
1000

title: Configs
content:
Configs
Setup configs for your organization or site.





Concepts
When working with AEM Edge Delivery Services and Document Authoring, you will work with several different types of configs depending on the context of what task you are trying to accomplish.


style
center, container


spacing-top
800


spacing-bottom
400





Sidekick Config - Where general Sidekick, plugins, and DA app configs live.
AEM Edge Delivery Config - All configs associated with your org or project.
DA Config (High performance) - Used to spec authentication information or anything that requires very fast response times. This can be set for an organization or site.
DA Config (Legacy) - Used to spec basic DA library details when high performance is not required. This can be set for a site.



Organization Config
Adding users

Visit: https://da.live/config#/name-of-org/ (or click the org breadcrumb settings icon in the browse view)
Add key | value column headers if they don't exist already.
Add admin.role.all | [email protected]
Paper plane > Save











Site Config
Adding AEM integration
The AEM integration provides an out of the box way to work with your AEM assets. It also allows you to use the DA App SDK to build rich applications that leverages any content stored on your AEM as a Cloud Service instance.
Step 1 - AEM as a Cloud Service
An AEM environment config will need to be set. Details in the screenshot below. Expect a full restart (~10-20 minutes) when this is saved.
Environment Configuration: ADOBE_PROVIDED_CLIENT_ID | darkalley








Step 2 - Dark Alley

Visit: https://da.live/config#/name-of-org/name-of-site/
Add key | value if it doesn't exist already.
Add aem.repositoryId | sub.youraemcloud.com
Paper plane > Save

Step 3 - Use it
Open any page and notice you have a new image icon in your toolbar. This will connect you to your AEM Assets.

title: Translation, localization, and rollout
content:
Translation, localization, and rollout
Setup translation, localization, and rollout for DA.





Vocabulary

Translate - The act of taking a document in a specific language and converting it a different language.
Localize - Converting a document to have more locale-centric or regionally-centric content.
Rollout - The technical term for copying documents from a language folder and into a locale or region.



Introduction
Document Authoring (DA) provides several services to help automate the translation, localization, and rollout of content. While on-demand services like Google Translate or even built-in browser translations can be convenient, they can have non-ideal SEO impacts.
One of the hallmark features of Adobe Experience Manager (AEM) is the ability to automate the process of translating, localizing, and rolling out content. In many respects, DA is no different. It provides many similar features, but with a focus on document-based authoring.
Managing localized content at scale can be a challenge due to the amount of content that is created. DA gives you, the site owner, the freedom to be as high-touch or hands-off as needed for your project. For example: you are free to organize your site by language or by locale. You are free to auto-publish after rollout or require human authors to curate newly created content.


Strategy
As we alluded to above, it's important to pick a localization strategy that fits your needs. Adobe's best practices can be read on aem.live. For our setup, we will follow the hybrid approach outlined in the best practices doc. A hybrid approach allows you to be mostly language-based, but provide affordances for locale-based content as necessary. This might be used for events in a region or used for locales where a dialect differs significantly from the source language and you have native speaking authors that can augment the translated content for the locale.
Language Only

/en
/fr
/de
/cn

Locale Only

/en-us
/en-ca
/en-in
/fr-fr
/fr-ca
/de-de
/zh-cn

Hybrid

/en
/en/us
/fr
/fr/ca
/de
/de/ch
/zh
/zh/

High-level considerations
While a language-based approach can provide less overhead, you may run into complexities with commerce, currencies, and VAT.
A locale-based approach may provide simplicity in commerce, but it will create undesired duplication of content that is unfriendly for SEO.
A hybrid model where the site is predominantly language-based keeps content duplication low. You will still have similar language-based commerce considerations, but this would be considered the preferred option over locale-based.
Translation configuration
Because every site is different, DA provides a few configuration options to help you manage your content.


translate.behavior - How to handle old content when new docs come back from translation.

overwrite - Overwrite the old content. Useful for no-touch translation.
merge - Merge the old content with the new content. Useful if there is content you want to retain. This option requires human intervention after translation.



translate.staging - Stage content in a separate area from your source content before sending to translation service.

on - This will copy your source content into a separate folder. This is typically done to make changes to your source docs before sending to translation but not affecting your live content.
off - Send source documents directly to the translation service.



rollout.behavior - How to handle old content when new docs get rolled out to the locale. This is only used for hybrid and locale-based localization strategies.

overwrite - Overwrite the old content. Useful for no-touch translation.
merge - Merge the old content with the new content. Useful if there is content you want to retain. This option requires human intervention after translation.











key
value


translate.behavior
overwrite








style
container

title: AEM Assets
content:
AEM Assets
Setup AEM Assets for your site.





Site Config
Adding AEM integration
The AEM integration provides an out of the box way to work with your AEM assets. It also allows you to use the DA App SDK to build rich applications that leverages any content stored on your AEM as a Cloud Service instance.
Step 1 - AEM as a Cloud Service
An AEM environment config will need to be set. Details in the screenshot below. Expect a full restart (~10-20 minutes) when this is saved.
Environment Configuration: ADOBE_PROVIDED_CLIENT_ID | darkalley








Step 2 - Dark Alley

Visit: https://da.live/config#/name-of-org/name-of-site/
Add key | value if it doesn't exist already.
Add aem.repositoryId | sub.youraemcloud.com
Paper plane > Save

Step 3 - Use it

Open any page and notice you have a new image icon in your toolbar. This will open a modal to your AEM Assets.
Select the asset you want and it will import into your document.
The asset must be published for DA & Edge Delivery Services to see it.

Use cases
In addition to having all the existing benefits of AEM Assets (governance, etc.), there are a couple use cases that can be unlocked related to DA:

Swapping an existing asset with an updated version.
Bulk replacing an image.

It's important to know that even if you change a single asset, if that asset is used on 1000 pages, you will need to re-preview and re-publish those 1000 pages for Edge Delivery Services to ingest the new image and update the references on aem.page and aem.live.
Use case 1: Swap an existing asset
User story: As an author, I would like to update an existing asset with more vibrant colors without having to change every page the asset is currently used on.

On da.live, use the side navigation panel to navigate to your assets using the "files" icon.
In Adobe Experience Manager Assets, navigate to the folder that contains the asset you want to replace.
Replace the asset and re-publish it.
Navigate to a page in DA that uses the asset in question.
Due to caching constraints, it may take up to a few minutes for the asset to update.
Once you can see your changes reflected, Edge Delivery is ready to ingest it. Copy the asset publish URL.
Paste the asset publish URL into DA's search. This will list every page on DA that is using the asset.
Use the the share button (action bar > share icon) to copy the AEM URLs.
Paste the URLs into DA's bulk preview & publish tool (da.live/apps/bulk). Run a preview & publish on these URLs.

Note: If you have staged content updates in DA that are not currently live, the bulk preview and publish tools will push these live. You will want to take the necessary steps to ensure you are not pre-maturely publishing page updates as a result of this change.
